comment: Kasparov had a fondness for this system of Petrosian's in the 1980s.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4
comment: This method of seeking early exchanges is distinctly dubious.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2
comment: From a strategical standpoint, this move refutes Black's opening. Now Black can retreat with 7...Bb7 but after 8.e4, White has a distinct positional advantage.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3
comment: Now that the Black bishop has departed from the h1-a8 diagonal, Kasparov takes it for himself.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6
comment: It would seem more appropriate to play 8...c6 9.Bg2 d5, but after 10.0-0, White has the freer and easier game to play.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6
comment: Andersson seeks counterplay with b6-b5, but his lag in development is a cause for concern.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5
comment: After 10...d5 11.Bb2 Be7 12.Rc1 Qd7 13.Bg2 0-0 14.cxd5 exd5 15.Qb3, White has a clear advantage.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7
comment: Ulf Andersson has a reputation for being a very patient and solid defender, and thus a very difficult man to beat. This retreat of the knight has a view to the maneuver Na7-c8, followed by d7-d5 and Nc8-d6-c4. But White has some moves first!

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4
comment: Exploiting the misplaced "Queen's Indian bishop. "

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6
comment: Better was 13...h5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5
comment: A strong positional pawn sacrifice that opens the long diagonal for White's dark-squared bishop.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O
comment: White's compensation for his pawn is enormous - a massive lead in development, two raking bishops, and a weakness on g7 that prevents Black catching up in development in a normal manner.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1
comment: The target is the Black king, with the e3-e4 break scheduled.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5
comment: Now after the inevitable exchange of light-squared bishops, White will have the g6-square at his disposal as an invasion point for his queen.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4
comment: Now there are all manner of tactics brewing against the f6 and g7 points in the Black position.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4 Nc8

1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4 Nc8 23. Rad1 Ra7
comment: Also hopeless is 23...d5 24.Nxf6! gxf6 (24...Bxf6 25.Qg6+ Kf8 26.Bxf6 gxf6 27.Re6! wins for White.) 25.Qg6+ Kf8 26.Bc1 Qe8 (26...Ra7 represents a transposition to the game.) 27.Bxh6+ Rxh6 28.Qxh6+ Kg8 29.Rd4, and the Black king is doomed.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4 Nc8 23. Rad1 Ra7 24. Nxf6 gxf6
comment: White also wins after 24...Bxf6 25.Qg6+ Kf8 26.Bxf6 gxf6 27.Re6.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4 Nc8 23. Rad1 Ra7 24. Nxf6 gxf6 25. Qg6+ Kf8 26. Bc1 d5
comment: Nor can Black defend after 26...Qe8 27.Bxh6+ Rxh6 28.Qxh6+ Kg8 29.Rd4 f5 30.Qg5+! Kh8 31.Qxf5.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4 Nc8 23. Rad1 Ra7 24. Nxf6 gxf6 25. Qg6+ Kf8 26. Bc1 d5 27. Rd4 Nd6 28. Rg4 Nf7 29. Bxh6+
comment: A final knock-out punch. The bishop cannot be captured because of immediate mate.

moves: 1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nf3 b6 4. a3 Bb7 5. Nc3 Ne4 6. Nxe4 Bxe4 7. Nd2 Bg6 8. g3 Nc6 9. e3 a6 10. b4 b5 11. cxb5 axb5 12. Bb2 Na7 13. h4 h6 14. d5 exd5 15. Bg2 c6 16. O-O f6 17. Re1 Be7 18. Qg4 Kf7 19. h5 Bh7 20. e4 dxe4 21. Bxe4 Bxe4 22. Nxe4 Nc8 23. Rad1 Ra7 24. Nxf6 gxf6 25. Qg6+ Kf8 26. Bc1 d5 27. Rd4 Nd6 28. Rg4 Nf7 29. Bxh6+ Ke8 30. Bg7
comment:
Black Resigned 
After the forced 30...Rg8, then simply 31.h6 decides the issue. A powerful tour de force by Kasparov.
